metadata.case_name: Petitioners in Writ Petitions Nos. 78-80, 93 and 152 of 1956 v. Union of India

facts.text: Pursuant to resolutions passed by legislatures of several States under Art. 252(1) of the Constitution, Parliament enacted Prize Competitions Act, 42 of 1955, brought into force on April 1, 1956.
Petitioners are engaged in promoting and conducting prize competitions in different States of India.

Section 2(d) defines 'prize competition' as any competition in which prizes are offered for solution of puzzle based on building up, arrangement, combination or permutation of letters, words or figures.
Section 4 prohibits promoting/conducting prize competitions where total prize value exceeds Rs.1000 per month or entries exceed 2000.
Section 5 requires licence for prize competitions where total prize value does not exceed Rs.1000 per month.
Rule 11 regulates entry fees: maximum Re.1 for prizes Rs.500-1000, 8 as. for Rs.250-500, 4 as. for below Rs.250; entry fee in money only.
Rule 12 requires maintenance of register in Form C, receipt of entries at licensed place, serial numbering, accept only first 2000 entries, refund excess if fee charged.
Genesis in Bombay Lotteries and Prize Competitions Control and Tax Act (Bom. LIV of 1948), applied initially within Bombay, licensing under s.7, tax under s.12.
To prevent evasion, Bombay Act XXX of 1952 extended to competitions outside Bombay but operating inside, tax on entries from Bombay.
Bombay High Court held competitions gambling, licensing valid but taxes hit Art.301 (subject of Civil Appeal No.134/1956).
States including Bombay passed resolutions under Art.252(1) authorizing Parliament to control and regulate prize puzzle competitions.

legal_issues.text: Whether prize competition as defined in s.2(d) includes competitions in which success depends to a substantial degree on skill and not merely those depending on chance.
Whether ss.4,5 and rr.11,12, void as to skill competitions, are severable and enforceable against gambling competitions.

petitioner_arguments.text: Definition in s.2(d) includes competitions depending substantially on skill; conditions in ss.4,5 and rr.11,12 unworkable, encroach on right to carry on business under Art.19(1)(g); unreasonable, amount to prohibition not regulation.
Even if reasonable for gambling, not for skill competitions; Act single inseverable enactment, fails in entirety.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Principle of severability; Punjab Province v. Daulat Singh; Romesh Thappar v. State of Madras; Chintaman Rao v. State of MP

respondent_arguments.text: Prize competition in s.2(d) means only those where success does not depend substantially on skill, essentially gambling.
Even if definition wide, provisions severable; valid for gambling competitions.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: F.N. Balsara; United Motors; In re Hindu Women's Rights

respondent_arguments.text: Restrictions not saved by Art.19(6) for skill competitions conceded on record.

court_reasoning.text: Gambling competitions not trade or business under Art.19(1)(g), following Civil Appeal No.134/1956; no need to consider reasonableness under Art.19(6).
Skill competitions protected under Art.19(1)(g); restrictions in ss.4,5, rr.11,12 not reasonable (conceded).
History of legislation (Bombay Act, evasion, resolutions under Art.252(1)) shows Act targets gambling competitions only; word 'control' indicates this.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Literal construction not conclusive; consider aim, scope, object, history per Heydon's case, Bengal Immunity

court_reasoning.text: Even if s.2(d) includes skill, provisions severable: gambling and skill distinct categories; legislature would enact for gambling; no rewriting needed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Severability applies whether invalidity from subject-matter or constitutional prohibitions (Balsara, United Motors)

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Punjab v. Daulat Singh (indivisible subject), Romesh Thappar, Chintaman Rao (inseverable provisions).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Valid parts enforceable if separate, complete

holdings.text: Prize Competitions Act applies only to competitions where success does not depend to substantial degree on skill (gambling character).
Ss.4,5 and rr.11,12 severable; valid and enforceable against gambling competitions.

statutes_cited.relevance: Genesis of legislation; licensing and tax

outcome.summary: Petitions challenging validity of ss.4,5 and rr.11,12 of Prize Competitions Act, 1955 dismissed; provisions held valid for gambling prize competitions as severable and definition interpreted to exclude skill-based ones.

key_quotes.text: Gambling is not trade but res extra commercium, and does not fall within the purview of Art.19(1)(g).
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on gambling not protected as business

key_quotes.text: The competitions which are sought to be controlled and regulated by the Act are only those competitions in which success does not depend to any substantial degree on skill.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interpretation of s.2(d) based on legislative history

key_quotes.text: When a statute is in part void, it will be enforced as regards the rest, if that is severable from what is invalid.
key_quotes.speaker: court
